_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Energy Transfer Marketing & Terminals 
Waskom Marketing Terminal
The Energy Transfer Marketing & Terminals (ETM&T) Waskom Marketing Terminal, hereafter referred to as the "Stationary Source", is a refined petroleum product storage and distribution stationary source in Harrison County, TX. A new butane system was constructed in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA Code) #58 for Liquified Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is the Stationary Source's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws/codes.

This Risk Management Program (RMP) covers the butane system only, including the butane offload station, butane storage tank (30,000 gal), butane transfer pump, and associated butane piping.
Two requirements of this section specifically apply to operations at the Stationary Source:

1.	Purpose and General Duty Clause - The essence of the General Duty Clause is that an owner/operator that stores and uses hazardous chemicals in any quantity has a fundamental obligation to ensure a safe operation and to have plans in place in the event of a loss of containment to appropriately manage the situation.

ETM&T is committed to ensuring the safe operation of the Stationary Source, as well as all of its other operations, to ensure a safe workplace for employees and a safe location for neighbors in the community. ETM&T has procedures in place to prevent accidents and is committed to emergency preparedness both for the Stationary Source and community-wide and coordinates with the Waskom Fire Department.

2.	Risk Management Plan - The primary function of the Stationary Source is to act as a flammable liquid storage and distribution Stationary Source. Due to the flammable effects associated with butane; it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. The Stationary Source is strongly com

he Stationary Source does not have a trained fire brigade or hazardous material response team, but outside emergency services may be called in to assist. The Stationary Sources emergency response plan is coordinated with the fire departments and the Delaware County LEPC. The Waskom Fire Department is aware of the system and its hazards. The Stationary Source has available protection systems (site fire extinguishers, emergency shut-off devices) and Emergency Response Procedures. The Waskom Marketing Terminal is a non-responding Stationary Source.
The Stationary Source is new and has not had any accidental releases during the past five years that meet the criteria for an accidental release as discussed in 40 CFR 68.42.

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, ETM&T looks for and seeks employee input on process safety improvements. Additionally, the Waskom Fire Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills which involve potential releases. 

With these objectives in mind, the Risk Management Plan has been developed to provide information regarding the management of the risks associated with the flammable substance storage process. Above all, ETM&T stresses its commitment to ensuring a safe working environment for employees, visitors and the community.
